text:
I've shown this idea to a few of you, but here's a more complete version: <http://timabram.com/NPSwebcam/index.html>
I'll post the python code soon, but basically it involves scraping images from all 137 national park webcams for an entire day, animating each as a timelapse video, uploading these to a youtube playlist (through the youtube api), and updating a geojson file containing the geocoords of each park cam and its video link that gets read into a leaflet map. The plan is to link these functions and schedule them to run automatically so that the videos update daily.
hey <@U064KUGRJ> cool project! i like the idea, the icons and everything. it doesn’t render correctly for me on Chrome right now though - I’ll post a screenshot
thanks <@U061A5N1G>! i'll take a look at the screenshot - could be the basemap tiles...
The timelapse looks so cool!  Hehe want to do a quick lightning talk on this this evening?
i would but i can't make it tonight :disappointed:

Yeah the tiles were all over the place before… but when I tried reloading to take the screenshot, it renders perfectly. The timelapses are so fun to look at! I need to stop because I can see myself doing this all day.
Ah man :disappointed:

A couple pcs of feedback: 1) sometimes clicking on the marker doesn’t work, you have to go next to it to get the clicky finger. Not sure what can be done about that. 2) when I move my cursor away from a playing timelapse, the timelapse closes, maybe it should continue playing at least until i click away from it?
Hehe it's also funny how you can tell which cameras need some focus
yea ive noticed that too. I think i can add some extra user interaction events on the mouseover/click to improve that
can this interface help me track where all the Pokemons are? Asking for a friend
<@U064SRKPD>: and some have bug issues :wink: <https://youtu.be/jPBStC0FxNg>
Hahhaha.  Wait so... You write them to videos?  I was thinking you were playing through images in a loop

there's probably a better way, but i have a script that converts the image sequences to .mkv videos, and then uploads to youtube. Then all I have to do is refresh the href youtube link to get updated videos.
It's also cool that you can loop embedded youtube videos, so it may not be too obvious
wow
so cool
<@U061A3E0G>: absolutely! (and I'm sure you've seen this: <http://www.bbc.co.uk/newsbeat/article/36757858/pokemon-go-player-finds-dead-body-in-wyoming-river-while-searching-for-a-pokestop>)
Seriously though, amazing project!
